com.swoval.files

Class QuickList

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.swoval.files.QuickList

  • public abstract class QuickList
extends java.lang.Object
    Provides a fast method list(Path, int, boolean) for listing the files in a directory. The file list apis present in File and Files can be slow for recursive directory listing because determining the type of file requires a stat. The three major platforms (Linux, Mac OS, Windows) all have native apis that allow the caller to list the files in the directory and include the types of the listed files. The NativeQuickLister uses these apis to speed up the performance. This can improve the performance of recursively listing a directory with many children by a large amount. For example, on a 2017 macbook pro, listing a directory with 5000 subdirectories containing one file takes roughly 25ms with QuickList, but roughly 100ms using Files.walkFileTree(java.nio.file.Path, java.util.Set<java.nio.file.FileVisitOption>, int, java.nio.file.FileVisitor<? super java.nio.file.Path>). It also takes roughly 75ms to stat all of the files (via Files.readAttributes(Path, Class, LinkOption...)) returned by the list(java.nio.file.Path, int), explaining the difference in performance.

    The implementation may be controlled using the system property -Dswoval.quicklister. For example, to make this class use the java nio based implementation, the application could be started with -Dswoval.quicklister=com.swoval.files.NioQuickLister.

    • Method Detail

      • list

        public static java.util.List<QuickFile> list(java.nio.file.Path path,
                                             int maxDepth)
                                      throws java.io.IOException
        Lists the files and directories in path following symbolic links. For a symbolic link to a directory, the results will contain the children of the symbolic link target relative to the symbolic link base. For example, if /foo contains a symbolic link called dir-link that links to /bar where /bar contains a file named baz, then the results will include a QuickFile for /foo/dir-link/baz (provided that the maxDepth >= 1).
        Parameters:
        path - The path to list
        maxDepth - The maximum maxDepth of the file system tree to traverse
        Returns:
        a List of QuickFile instances
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - when the path isn't listable because it isn't a directory, access is denied or the path doesn't exist. May also throw due to any io error.

      • list

        public static java.util.List<QuickFile> list(java.nio.file.Path path,
                                             int maxDepth,
                                             boolean followLinks)
                                      throws java.io.IOException
        Lists the files and directories in path following symbolic links. When followLinks is true, for a symbolic link to a directory, the results will contain the children of the symbolic link target relative to the symbolic link base. For example, if /foo contains a symbolic link called dir-link that links to /bar where /bar contains a file named baz, then the results will include a QuickFile for /foo/dir-link/baz (provided that the maxDepth >= 1).
        Parameters:
        path - The path to list
        maxDepth - The maximum depth of the file system tree to traverse
        followLinks - Toggles whether or not to follow symbolic links in the path
        Returns:
        a List of QuickFile instances
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - when the path isn't listable because it isn't a directory, access is denied or the path doesn't exist. May also throw due to any io error.

      • list

        public static java.util.List<QuickFile> list(java.nio.file.Path path,
                                             int maxDepth,
                                             boolean followLinks,
                                             Filter<? super QuickFile> filter)
                                      throws java.io.IOException
        Lists the files and directories in path. When followLinks is true, for a symbolic link to a directory, the results will contain the children of the symbolic link target relative to the symbolic link base. For example, if /foo contains a symbolic link called dir-link that links to /bar where /bar contains a file named baz, then the results will include a QuickFile for /foo/dir-link/baz (provided that the maxDepth >= 1). Files and directories that do not pass the filter are discarded.
        Parameters:
        path - The path to list
        maxDepth - The maximum depth of the file system tree to traverse
        followLinks - Toggles whether or not to follow symbolic links in the path
        filter - Files passing this function are returned
        Returns:
        a List of QuickFile instances
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - when the path isn't listable because it isn't a directory, access is denied or the path doesn't exist. May also throw due to any io error.
